ETYMOLOGY: From Old French remanant, present participle of remanoir 'to remain', from Latin remanēre (re- 'back, again' + manēre 'to remain').
SINCE: Late 14th century (as noun), mid-15th century (as adjective)

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A small remaining part or quantity of something, especially after the main part has been used or removed.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 某物所剩的少量部分或残余，尤指主体部分已被使用或移除后剩下的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She used the remnant of fabric to make a small pouch.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她用那块布料的残余部分做了一个小袋子。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A surviving trace, fragment, or vestige, often referring to a surviving portion of a group or people.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 幸存的痕迹、碎片或残迹，常指某个群体或民族的幸存部分。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The archaeologist discovered remnants of an ancient civilization.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 考古学家发现了古老文明的遗迹。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word or phrase naming an attribute, added to or grammatically related to a noun to modify or describe it.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Remaining; left over after the greater part has been used, removed, or destroyed.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 剩余的；在大部分被使用、移除或摧毁后留下来的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The remnant population struggled to rebuild their city.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 剩余的人口努力重建他们的城市。

REGISTER: Formal to general usage, depending on context.
